title: Nasdaq Files With SEC to Allow Trading of Tokenized Stocks - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Nasdaq has asked the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for a rule change that would allow the stock exchange to record stocks in tokenized form, according to a filing Monday, as momentum for tokenizing assets grows.
The exchange, which lists Apple, Google, Amazon, Meta, and other tech giants, would give customers the option of trading securities via traditional digital representation of ownership with or without blockchain backing.
In June, Robinhood rolled out trading for European users of U.S.-listed stocks and exchange-traded funds as tokens on Arbitrum, the Ethereum layer-2 scaling network.
In May, crypto exchange Kraken announced its own tokenization plans through a partnership with Backed, using the Solana blockchain.
The offering would cover more than 50 U.S.-listed stocks and exchange-traded funds.

title: Non-Recourse vs. Recourse Debt Explained: Definitions and Examples - Investopedia
summary:
Unlike recourse debt, where lenders can seek out borrowers to cover any remaining debt after seizing collateral, non-recourse loans offer more borrower protection.
What Sets Non-Recourse Debt Apart?
Non-recourse debt is riskier for lenders than recourse debt, especially if the collateral's value drops below the amount owed.
Recourse debt lets lenders seek more money from borrowers if collateral doesn't cover the debt.
Comparing Recourse and Non-Recourse Debt Recourse debt allows creditors to collect the full debt amount from the borrower if they default.

Unlike equities, the private credit market has long suffered from slow processes, opacity, and heavy friction.
So the full life cycle of that private credit is now on blockchain in real time.” He described this shift as an “inflection point” for tokenization, with adoption increasing significantly as institutions search for more efficient ways to manage credit.
